measured_by: 7-point Likert item "This explanation/advice is morally correct"
justification: Participants “rated the morality of the justification ("This explanation is morally correct")… on scales from 1: Strongly disagree to 7: Strongly agree.”

measured_by: 7-point Likert item "I agree with this explanation"
justification: The survey included the item “the correctness of the justification ("I agree with this explanation")” rated on the same 1–7 scale.

measured_by: 7-point Likert item "I trust the person who wrote this explanation/advice"
justification: Participants also rated “the trustworthiness of the justification ("I trust the person who wrote this explanation")” using the 7-point agreement scale.

measured_by: 7-point Likert item "This explanation/advice takes the nuances of the situation into account"
justification: Nuance was assessed with the statement “This explanation takes the nuances of the situation into account,” again on the 1–7 agreement scale.
Thoughtfulness was measured by agreement with the item “This explanation is thoughtful” on the same Likert scale.

measured_by: Extended Moral Foundations Dictionary (eMFD) word-probability scores
justification: “We operationalize moral language using the extended Moral Foundations Dictionary (eMFD), which approximates the degree of moral themes in a text based on the prevalence of words associated with morality.”
“As an additional exploratory measure, we also conducted sentiment analysis using the VADER lexicon, which measures the strength and prevalence of positive versus negative sentiment in text.”
“Two research assistants independently coded the advice for empathy on a scale from 1: ‘Not at all empathetic’ to 6: ‘Extremely empathetic’ (Cronbach’s alpha = .56).”

measured_by: Absolute difference between their moral ratings of each scenario
justification: “We measured moral alignment… by calculating the absolute differences in their moral ratings of the scenarios.”
construct: Moral alignment between writer and participant

measured_by: 1–10 rating of harm dimension (Dyadic Morality prompt)
justification: The GPT prompt asked for “scores between one and ten” on “harm… derived from the theory of dyadic morality.”
The same prompt asked for a numeric score for “help,” representing benefits provided.
GPT was instructed to rate “vulnerability of those affected” on a 1–10 scale as an intermediate reasoning step.
The chain-of-thought prompt included a 1–10 score for “intentionality of the act.”

measured_by: Single-choice item selecting which justification/advice was AI-generated
justification: “Participants were next directed to a question in which they selected which of the four justifications they believed was written by AI.”
